description: From French natron, from Spanish natrón, from Arabic نَطْرُون‎ (naṭrūn), from Ancient Greek νίτρον (nítron, “nitre”), ultimately from Egyptian nṯrj (“natron”):

entries.meaning: (mineralogy) A crystalline mixture of hydrous sodium carbonate and sodium bicarbonate, with the chemical formula Na2CO3·10H2O.
examples: Natron and salt are soluble by liquid, but not all liquid but only such as is cold.  Hence water and any of its varieties melt them, but oil does not.
